commit_message:
Add Armada job for testing update of release uuids

This adds both a periodic and experimental job for deploying Ceph
and the LMA components via Armada. This job will then generate a
new release uuid, render an updated manifest for all previously
deployed releases, then apply that manifest to validate the
ability for all deployed charts to update successfully with the
new release uuid annotation

Change-Id: Ic1eed1bd949279f4630fb3964fbb03788536213c

https://github.com/openstack/rally/commit/8bf5ceaa7c7c648381039dfc6223eb949b0be649#diff-0bdd949ed8a7fdd4f95240bd951779c8"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-01-31 19:37:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> @Doug: I'm talking about next changes:
 > 
 > https://github.com/openstack/rally/commit/ffe6fedf5bd20b32bbe3b10aef356c5e05725649#diff-0bdd949ed8a7fdd4f95240bd951779c8
 > https://github.com/openstack/rally/commit/3eeb0dd92c270bb8e7b8a67a0b596d2f49b90cf9#diff-0bdd949ed8a7fdd4f95240bd951779c8
 > https://github.com/openstack/rally/commit/8bf5ceaa7c7c648381039dfc6223eb949b0be649#diff-0bdd949ed8a7fdd4f95240bd951779c8

Why does rally have its own copy of upper-constraints.txt?

Is that list of "upper" constraints really the list of lower constraints? Or is it the list of exact versions that rally requires installed in order to work?'}, {'account_id': 9545, 'date': '2019-01-31 20:40:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

we created this file long time ago since we wanted to manage our requirements ourselves. I guess it had happened at the same period of time when we abandoned alignment with g-r.

we use u-c file to identify version which we suggest to use.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-02-01 13:38:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> we created this file long time ago since we wanted to manage our
 > requirements ourselves. I guess it had happened at the same period
 > of time when we abandoned alignment with g-r.
 > 
 > we use u-c file to identify version which we suggest to use.

Is the requirements.txt for rally accurate? Because we normally rely on changes to that file to tell when the dependencies of a project have been changed, so if you're taking a one-off special approach to managing that information I'm concerned."}, {'account_id': 9545, 'date': '2019-02-01 17:19:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Is the requirements.txt for rally accurate?

yes, sure! all our consumers are happy (mostly). there were just several issues over the last several years. One of these issues should be addressed with this proposed release.

> Because we normally rely on changes to that file to tell when the dependencies of a project have been changed, so if you're taking a one-off special approach to managing that information I'm concerned.

Rally doesn't follow g-r policy since 2016 year (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/328849/) which is 2.5 year now..."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-02-01 18:51:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> > Is the requirements.txt for rally accurate?
 > 
 > yes, sure! all our consumers are happy (mostly). there were just
 > several issues over the last several years. One of these issues
 > should be addressed with this proposed release.
 > 
 > > Because we normally rely on changes to that file to tell when the
 > dependencies of a project have been changed, so if you're taking a
 > one-off special approach to managing that information I'm
 > concerned.
 > 
 > Rally doesn't follow g-r policy since 2016 year (https://review.openstack.org/#/c/328849/)
 > which is 2.5 year now...

OK, I don't really know what to do with this. You're not following our standard community practices for managing dependencies, because the requirements.txt in the repo doesn't include any minimum versions. The list of actually usable versions is maintained in a completely separate file that isn't going to be used by pip or any of the tools that would build distro packages from the sdist (unless they're doing something custom, I suppose). None of that is standard.

It's possible to fix it without tying yourself to the global requirements process, so I'm not suggesting you should do that. But I don't feel comfortable releasing rally the way it is set up right now. I won't block the release, but I'll wait to see what some of the other release managers think."}, {'account_id': 9545, 'date': '2019-02-04 17:36:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Published edit on patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 9545, 'date': '2019-02-04 17:38:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

first of all, I updated the hash of commit we would like to make the release from. It includes updates in the main requirements.txt which is very important for releasing (conflict of licenses )'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-02-04 22:16:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
doc: Switch header styles in support doc

We typically use '-' for H2-type headers and '~' for H3-style. This
document was using the opposite which was mighty confusing for your dear
editor. Simply switch them around and reduce that confusion.

Change-Id: I69712bab7deeb75b3fe619c9d93a078f90b76dad
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2019-02-04 20:32:41.000000000', 'message': 'Adjusting NRPE script to work with Vault HA and non-SSL Vault

According to Vault docs https://www.vaultproject.io/api/system/health.html,
in standby mode it will return non-200 code by default, causing our current
NRPE script to fail. This change is enforcing Vault to return HTTP 200 for
both active and standby units.

Also, a fix for lp:1813989 is here since Vault is running its healtcheck
interface on loopback interface only using port 8220.

Change-Id: I47a192396ac18b0f3ea1ea60715e150bd841c7cb
Closes-Bug: #1813989
Closes-Bug: #1814323
'}]
commit_message:
Adjusting NRPE script to work with Vault HA and non-SSL Vault

According to Vault docs https://www.vaultproject.io/api/system/health.html,
in standby mode it will return non-200 code by default, causing our current
NRPE script to fail. This change is enforcing Vault to return HTTP 200 for
both active and standby units.

Also, a fix for lp:1813989 is here since Vault is running its healtcheck
interface on loopback interface only using port 8220.

Change-Id: I47a192396ac18b0f3ea1ea60715e150bd841c7cb
Closes-Bug: #1813989
Closes-Bug: #1814323

When doing a docker inspect though, I see that apparently this bind mount's propagation is configured to be rprivate:

                "Mode": "ro",
                "RW": false,
                "Propagation": "rprivate"
            },

Which I guess seems to indicate that it works with private mount?

I'm re-testing quickly to validate that it works, and will do a password update with a standalone + podman as well'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-02-04 09:46:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Some fast local testing with rprivate showed all changes are propagated from the host just fine.'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2019-02-04 10:40:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2019-02-04 15:50:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 13039, 'date': '2019-02-04 15:50:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 13039, 'date': '2019-02-04 15:50:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2019-02-04 15:53:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-04 09:20:05.000000000', 'message': "mysql: sync credentials in running container on password change

Since 8e67ec833173920ac60b5548a711885a4d28e16f, docker-puppet doesn't
change mysql password config file on password update. It only notifies
of config change and paunch restarts some containers accordingly.

In non-HA mysql service, when a stack update changes the mysql password,
a docker-puppet task updates the root password config file at step 2.

However, the mysql container is started before the docker-puppet task,
which means that it gets the old root password config file from kolla
and it is never updated afterwards.

This discrepancy between the updated password and the password config
file in the mysql container makes it impossible to connect to mysql
without using a password at command line. This also breaks mysql's
post upgrade tasks which require the proper root credentials in the file.

Fix that discrepancy by adding a synchronization action at step3, which
will be triggered by paunch whenever a config change happens.

Note: this discrepancy does not happen for the HA version of the mysql
service, because we already have a container that is in charge of
restarting mysql on config change (mysql_restart_bundle).

Change-Id: I9cc725c77fd9a2f9e55c4878cd2125f99f35c06d
"}, {'created': '2019-02-04 09:30:28.000000000', 'message': "mysql: sync credentials in running container on password change

Since 8e67ec833173920ac60b5548a711885a4d28e16f, docker-puppet doesn't
change mysql password config file on password update. It only notifies
of config change and paunch restarts some containers accordingly.

In non-HA mysql service, when a stack update changes the mysql password,
a docker-puppet task updates the root password config file at step 2.

However, the mysql container is started before the docker-puppet task,
which means that it gets the old root password config file from kolla
and it is never updated afterwards.

This discrepancy between the updated password and the password config
file in the mysql container makes it impossible to connect to mysql
without using a password at command line. This also breaks mysql's
post upgrade tasks which require the proper root credentials in the file.

Fix that discrepancy by adding a synchronization action at step3, which
will be triggered by paunch whenever a config change happens.

Note: this discrepancy does not happen for the HA version of the mysql
service, because we already have a container that is in charge of
restarting mysql on config change (mysql_restart_bundle).

Change-Id: I9cc725c77fd9a2f9e55c4878cd2125f99f35c06d
Closes-Bug: #1814514

file in the mysql container makes it impossible to connect to mysql
without using a password at command line. This also breaks mysql's
post upgrade tasks which require the proper root credentials in the file.

Fix that discrepancy by adding a synchronization action at step3, which
will be triggered by paunch whenever a config change happens, and make
the docker-puppet task modify the config file shared with the mysql
container (from /var/lib/config-data/puppet-generated)

Note: this discrepancy does not happen for the HA version of the mysql
service, because we already have a container that is in charge of
restarting mysql on config change (mysql_restart_bundle).

Change-Id: I9cc725c77fd9a2f9e55c4878cd2125f99f35c06d
Closes-Bug: #1814514

commit_message:
mysql: sync credentials in running container on password change

Since 8e67ec833173920ac60b5548a711885a4d28e16f, docker-puppet doesn't
change mysql password config file on password update. It only notifies
of config change and paunch restarts some containers accordingly.

In non-HA mysql service, when a stack update changes the mysql password,
a docker-puppet task updates the root password config file at step 2.

However, the mysql container is started before the docker-puppet task,
which means that it gets the old root password config file from kolla
and it is never updated afterwards.

This discrepancy between the updated password and the password config
file in the mysql container makes it impossible to connect to mysql
without using a password at command line. This also breaks mysql's
post upgrade tasks which require the proper root credentials in the file.

Fix that discrepancy by adding a synchronization action at step3, which
will be triggered by paunch whenever a config change happens, and make
the docker-puppet task modify the config file shared with the mysql
container (from /var/lib/config-data/puppet-generated)

Note: this discrepancy does not happen for the HA version of the mysql
service, because we already have a container that is in charge of
restarting mysql on config change (mysql_restart_bundle).

Change-Id: I9cc725c77fd9a2f9e55c4878cd2125f99f35c06d
Closes-Bug: #1814514

commit_message:
Fixed UnicodeEncodeError for Python2 unicode objects

On python2 in case of unicode objects, str() was causing UnicodeEncodeError.
Also utf8 encoding as a default (mostly for Python2)

Change-Id: I64373133f65c5b11daa3462b7c21a55d06738c09
(cherry picked from commit 17b9e9d42c7d79e1a6e4fd60312ed39108eebab6)

[{'created': '2019-02-01 20:43:39.000000000', 'message': 'Adjusting NRPE script to work with Vault HA and non-SSL Vault

According to Vault docs https://www.vaultproject.io/api/system/health.html,
in standby mode it will return non-200 code by default, causing our current
NRPE script to fail. This change is enforcing Vault to return HTTP 200 for
both active and standby units.

Also, a workaround for lp:1813989 is here since in certain circumstances Vault can run
on HTTPS endpoint with plain HTTP (and causes clients to disconnect with
SSL: WRONG_VERSION_NUMBER error).

Change-Id: I47a192396ac18b0f3ea1ea60715e150bd841c7cb
Closes-Bug: #1813989
Closes-Bug: #1814323
'}, {'created': '2019-02-04 19:51:37.000000000', 'message': 'Adjusting NRPE script to work with Vault HA and non-SSL Vault

According to Vault docs https://www.vaultproject.io/api/system/health.html,
in standby mode it will return non-200 code by default, causing our current
NRPE script to fail. This change is enforcing Vault to return HTTP 200 for
both active and standby units.

Also, a fix for lp:1813989 is here since Vault is running its healtcheck
interface on loopback interface only using port 8220.

Change-Id: I47a192396ac18b0f3ea1ea60715e150bd841c7cb
Closes-Bug: #1813989
Closes-Bug: #1814323
'}]
commit_message:
Adjusting NRPE script to work with Vault HA and non-SSL Vault

According to Vault docs https://www.vaultproject.io/api/system/health.html,
in standby mode it will return non-200 code by default, causing our current
NRPE script to fail. This change is enforcing Vault to return HTTP 200 for
both active and standby units.

Also, a fix for lp:1813989 is here since Vault is running its healtcheck
interface on loopback interface only using port 8220.

Change-Id: I47a192396ac18b0f3ea1ea60715e150bd841c7cb
Closes-Bug: #1813989
Closes-Bug: #1814323

commit_message:
create a branch neutron-omnipath

This branch has been requested for use case of baremetals with
omnipath switching fabric, this branch will have the mechanism
driver code for omnipath switch along with other neutron stuff.
it will use vlan type driver for tenant networks.

networking-generic-switch could've been used for this purpose but
the it doesn't fulfill the scaling needs of the requirements hence
using separate mechanism driver in separate neutron branch.

Change-Id: Ib982bf159d24a741cf78d52243f3e6b0d54e4a12

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-16 00:34:45.000000000', 'message': "Use X-Forwarded-Proto as origin protocol if present

When using a haproxy with SSL termination to provide secure console
connections, haproxy will change the Origin header scheme to 'http'
and add the 'X-Forwarded-Proto: https' header. This causes a failure
in the Nova console proxy code which verifies that the Origin header
scheme matches the access_url scheme for the connection, because the
Origin header coming from haproxy is 'http' while the access_url
scheme is 'https' or 'wss'.

This looks for the X-Forwarded-Proto header and uses its scheme for
the verification instead, if it is present.

Closes-Bug: #1788180

Change-Id: I43401dc8368853654bf443273a0a1b5b9b63e3f0
"}]
commit_message:
Use X-Forwarded-Proto as origin protocol if present

When using a haproxy with SSL termination to provide secure console
connections, haproxy will change the Origin header scheme to 'http'
and add the 'X-Forwarded-Proto: https' header. This causes a failure
in the Nova console proxy code which verifies that the Origin header
scheme matches the access_url scheme for the connection, because the
Origin header coming from haproxy is 'http' while the access_url
scheme is 'https' or 'wss'.

This looks for the X-Forwarded-Proto header and uses its scheme for
the verification instead, if it is present.

Closes-Bug: #1788180

Change-Id: I43401dc8368853654bf443273a0a1b5b9b63e3f0

commit_message:
Add ContainerImagePrepare service to ControllerStorageNfs role

While using ControllerStorageNfs role images are not pushed to local registry,
since ContainerImagePrepare service is missing in ControllerStorageNfs role.

Closes-Bug: #1814057

Change-Id: Iafe7bf37d7d04eed32a32b8881fab48fdc9f9dd6

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-24 16:30:57.000000000', 'message': 'GoodnessWeigher schedules non-type volumes

If the GoodnessWeigher is configured to be the only active weigher within
the scheduler, it cannot schedule a non-typed volumed for creation. This
patch adds a safety assignement to the weigher stats generation to allow
for scheduling untyped volumes.

This patch safely assigns a dictionary data-type to "volume_type" in the
event that:

    weight_properties = {
        "volume_type": None,
        etc..
    }

Volumes created with a volume-type will not cause an exception and will
be scheduled with the volume-type and back-end as configured.

Closes-Bug: 1766966

Change-Id: I7bc77ab02154aee80282e54b19a242bdea0a78ec
Signed-off-by: Eric M Gonzalez <eric@awnix.com>
(cherry picked from commit 34d75ca1a6eea03bc0fe856bf1a63e7d8d60f024)
'}, {'created': '2019-01-24 20:21:33.000000000', 'message': 'GoodnessWeigher schedules non-type volumes

commit_message:
GoodnessWeigher schedules non-type volumes

If the GoodnessWeigher is configured to be the only active weigher within
the scheduler, it cannot schedule a non-typed volumed for creation. This
patch adds a safety assignement to the weigher stats generation to allow
for scheduling untyped volumes.

This patch safely assigns a dictionary data-type to "volume_type" in the
event that:

    weight_properties = {
        "volume_type": None,
        etc..
    }

Volumes created with a volume-type will not cause an exception and will
be scheduled with the volume-type and back-end as configured.

Closes-Bug: 1766966

Change-Id: I7bc77ab02154aee80282e54b19a242bdea0a78ec
Signed-off-by: Eric M Gonzalez <eric@awnix.com>
(cherry picked from commit 34d75ca1a6eea03bc0fe856bf1a63e7d8d60f024)

commit_message:
Update openstack-helm Armada job

This updates the openstack-helm Armada job to instead deploy
only Ceph, the OpenStack service charts, and their dependencies.
This is dependent on the addition of the Armada job for Ceph and
the LMA components to openstack-helm-infra. This also updates the
jobs definition to use the osh-gate-runner playbook instead, as
well as sets the job both to a periodic and experimental job

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/634676/
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/633067/
Change-Id: I7e191a153f123e04e123acc33fb691d8117062a9

commit_message:
Add endpoint tests for system member role

From keystone's perspective, the ``member`` and ``reader`` roles are
effectively the same, isolating writable endpoint operations to the
``admin`` role.

This commit adds explicit testing to make sure the ``member`` role
is allowed to perform readable and not writable endpoint operations.
Subsequent patches will incorporate:

 - system admin functionality
 - domains user test coverage
 - project user test coverage

Change-Id: Ia8ccd808e3863bad5539f6d6ee9ae53e1036b24a
Related-Bug: 1804482
Related-Bug: 1804483

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 24162, 'date': '2019-01-31 09:50:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21: Code-Review-1

do not find the creation of a shell script that contains variables and sourcing it on each execution as an improvement: it clearly does not make code easier to read, maintain or debug.

I would prefer to see one of the following approaches:
- use of ansible commands and passing environment vars
- consolidate few ansible tasks into an embedded shell command (not external file) *if* it ease the code logic

To be clear: i would not mind replacing all these ~10 ansible tasks with a single shell script that performs the resizing. but I am against
the combined use of ansible with shell which brings the worse of both worlds. 

Please check with others before doing something, it may be the only one with this view. If I am alone I will change my vote.'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2019-01-31 10:18:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 21:

commit_message:
Use force_tcg by libguestfs is not ok

Use force_tcg for virt-resize and virt-customize if the
libguestfs-test-tool fails.

Also dump virt-resize, virt-customize and libguestfs-test-tools to log files

Related-Bug: #1743749

Change-Id: Idb7b2be9900ef115f71379cfd7b9c3edf675119e

commit_message:
Scan templated python files with bandit

This change adds a zuul check job to export any templated python
contained in the helm charts and scan it with bandit for any
potential security flaws.

Change-Id: I982284c304a7c7533bf36b765b46f53b4c1f4aac

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-28 22:04:32.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Use a static resource tracker in the compute manager

There was one edge case in the compute manager wherein we would
reinitialize the resource tracker. Jay promises that isn't needed
anymore, so this change removes it. That allows us to remove the
_get_resource_tracker() helper and set up the resource tracker just once
during __init__ of the compute manager.

We also remove get_node_uuid, which doesn't seem to be used anywhere
other than test. (This may in fact mean it's not even possible to reach
the code path modified above, since get_node_uuid might be the only
place from which the relevant exception could have been raised.)

Change-Id: Ibb8c12fb2799bb5ceb9e3d72a2b86dbb4f14451e

commit_message:
Use a static resource tracker in compute manager

There was one edge case in the compute manager wherein we would
reinitialize the resource tracker. Jay promises that isn't needed
anymore, so this change removes it. That allows us to remove the
_get_resource_tracker() helper and set up the resource tracker just once
during __init__ of the compute manager.

Change-Id: Ibb8c12fb2799bb5ceb9e3d72a2b86dbb4f14451e

commit_message:
Fix E117 for pycodestyle 2.5.0

The new pycodestyle 2.5.0 enforces E117. This patch fixes code that was
over indented.

Change-Id: Iee8c7af8bcfc0721592cf008178150b464b6720e

[{'created': '2018-11-10 00:56:20.000000000', 'message': 'Rip out the SchedulerClient

Since all remaining SchedulerClient methods were direct passthroughs to
the SchedulerQueryClient, and nothing special is being done anymore to
instantiate that client, the SchedulerClient is no longer necessary. All
references to it are replaced with direct references to
SchedulerQueryClient.

commit_message:
Rip out the SchedulerClient

Since all remaining SchedulerClient methods were direct passthroughs to
the SchedulerQueryClient, and nothing special is being done anymore to
instantiate that client, the SchedulerClient is no longer necessary. All
references to it are replaced with direct references to
SchedulerQueryClient.

Change-Id: I57dd199a7c5e762d97a600307aa13a7aeb62d2b2

Sorry, forgot to respond to this bit:

> Eric, is there any way to detach this patch out of this series?

It's slightly easier this way since [1] removes two of the methods [2]. If I pull these out, I would need to swapo-changeo the code and tests using those two methods, only to remove them in [1].

> I think it would super useful to get this (and the next Rip out the SchedulerCLient) patch done without the other ones in this series.

The other ones in the series ought to be pretty much ready, and some feel we should merge them soon so they get plenty of burn-in time.

commit_message:
Rip the report client out of SchedulerClient

A step toward getting rid of the SchedulerClient intermediary, this
patch removes the reportclient member from SchedulerClient, instead
instantiating SchedulerReportClient directly wherever it's needed.

Change-Id: I14d1a648843c6311a962aaf99a47bb1bebf7f5ea

commit_message:
Add secret=true to fixed_key configuration parameter

Add secret=true to fixed_key configuration parameter as that value
shouldn't be logged.

Change-Id: I21e1246769213fb7b9e283c0ed3a369cbe780650
Closes-Bug: #1806473

commit_message:
Add Armada deployment job to openstack-helm-infra

This adds both a periodic and experimental job for deplying Ceph
and the LMA components via Armada to openstack-helm-infra

Change-Id: Ia3b557801d4f4b667d82eb47a6ef1825394ee526

subject: Ceph rgw chart code cleanup
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-04 18:44:21.000000000', 'message': 'Ceph rgw chart code cleanup

Change-Id: I11a72048f3c901753c4dcc3aaddbe897d084d210
'}, {'created': '2019-02-04 18:55:03.000000000', 'message': 'Ceph rgw chart code cleanup

Change-Id: I11a72048f3c901753c4dcc3aaddbe897d084d210
'}, {'created': '2019-02-04 19:04:23.000000000', 'message': "Ceph rgw chart code cleanup

Currently both 'deployment:rgw_keystone_user_and_endpoints`
and 'conf: rgw_ks' are used to deploy ceph-rgw with keystone
integration.

removing key:pair `rgw_keystone_user_and_endpoints: true`
to make code more cleaner.

Going forward, only `conf: rgw_ks: enabled: true` will be used
to deploy ceph-rgw with keystone integration.

Change-Id: I11a72048f3c901753c4dcc3aaddbe897d084d210
"}]
commit_message:
Ceph rgw chart code cleanup

Currently both 'deployment:rgw_keystone_user_and_endpoints`
and 'conf: rgw_ks' are used to deploy ceph-rgw with keystone
integration.

removing key:pair `rgw_keystone_user_and_endpoints: true`
to make code more cleaner.

Going forward, only `conf: rgw_ks: enabled: true` will be used
to deploy ceph-rgw with keystone integration.

Change-Id: I11a72048f3c901753c4dcc3aaddbe897d084d210

Fix missing print format error

Missing print format will cause 'ValueError: unsupported
format character' error, this is to fix it.

commit_message:
flatten the manila service configurations

This change combines the previous puppet and docker files into a single
file that performs the docker service installation and configuration
for all manila services.

With this patch the baremetal version of each manila service has been removed.

Related-Blueprint: services-yaml-flattening

Change-Id: I02addc0ecbbbcb60d2c6a0d30d7c9cfa42346f7c

commit_message:
TLS everywhere: Mount the whole /etc/pki/libvirt/ directory in libvirt

We need to mount the whole directory inside the libvirt container,
so that when new certificates are generated, they could be accessed from
within the container.

Related-Bug: #1811401
Co-Authored-By: Juan Antonio Osorio Robles <jaosorior@redhat.com>
Change-Id: I3f1e7511d56f9a974409a9a1e3ed66ba8fa72e36

commit_message:
TLS everywhere: Set post-save command for neutron dhcpd

The default procedure wasn't working, here we set one that will actually work.

The script additionally copies the certificates in the right place.

Related-Bug: #1811401
Depends-On: I9954cf33efedf2ec3dfb03109595cd4431feff60
Change-Id: I449df13ea2c49a8cf6d2e8e632b2b39707071c52

commit_message:
TLS everywhere: Set post-save command for nova-vnc-proxy

The default command wasn't working, here we set one that will actually work.

The script additionally copies the certificates in the right place.

Related-Bug: #1811401
Depends-On: Ifacbee9e31d84be1008ab7545defac71cf65793f
Change-Id: Idc0844c8726aa53bc4cbd55f902248f854d2464f

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-01 16:21:23.000000000', 'message': 'Catch directories we can not change ownership

When there is a directory where the owner can not be changed, we
fail and do not proceed to check the remaining directories. This
has been seen where netapp creates a special .snapshot directory
which is protected and visible when useing NFSv3, not visible
when using NFSv4.

This change catches the error and proceeds.

Change-Id: I2e61030c863041cd73cb204e31e423da3c6f6944
Resolves-Bug: 1814260
'}]
commit_message:
Catch directories we can not change ownership

When there is a directory where the owner can not be changed, we
fail and do not proceed to check the remaining directories. This
has been seen where netapp creates a special .snapshot directory
which is protected and visible when useing NFSv3, not visible
when using NFSv4.

This change catches the error and proceeds.

Change-Id: I2e61030c863041cd73cb204e31e423da3c6f6944
Resolves-Bug: 1814260

commit_message:
Run nova_statedir_owner on every run

So far nova_statedir_owner step is only run on initial deploy or
when the image changes. This runs it on every deploy/scale/...
run.

Related-Bug: 1814260

Change-Id: I5eaaad9371183dff070d0eb72457fb76a6a60ebe

commit_message:
Reject resize with port having resource request

Nova does not consider the resource request of a Neutron port as of now.
So this patch makes sure that server resize request is rejected if it
involves a port that has resource request. When the feature is ready on
the nova side this limitation will be lifted.

Note that the api sample tests for server actions needed to split into
two test class. The floating ip tests are moved to a new class as those
tests are not supporting Neutron yet. For the rest neutron is now used
in the test. This was necessary as now the resize action depending on
neutron a neturon only feature, i.e. listing ports.

blueprint: bandwidth-resource-provider

Change-Id: I61a3e8902a891bac36911812e4e7c080570e3850

commit_message:
Add tripleo-ci-centos-7-standalone-os-tempest job

Since https://review.openstack.org/#/c/627500 marks the integration
of os_tempest in tripleo ci, it is good to have a job here to make
sure that it does not break tripleo integration.

Change-Id: Ib6f2589b45a2273b124d78567d1da7c4cf605997

commit_message:
Delete db resources not in template

When migrating stacks to convergence, if there are resources in
the database that are not in the current_template_id of the stack,
they are possibly of no isue, so it would better to delete those
resources from db to avoid any future update issues.

Change-Id: Ica99cec6765d22d7ee2262e2d402b2e98cb5bd5e
Story: #2004071
Task: 27092
(cherry picked from commit 43583b4a323e15b13e288b3a6f78500e442b7402)

commit_message:
Remove morph dependency

morph library is distributed under GPLv3 dependency which means that we
need to distribute under package as well under GPLv3 license or stop
using this library.

Since we do not use too much from morph, so let's just let's write a
simple replacement for what we actually need.

Change-Id: I00df4e66a2365cbaa948707289b14262dc016454

subject: Add Version Based Feature Discovery in Technical Vision
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 2, 'name': 'Monty Taylor', 'email': 'mordred@inaugust.com', 'username': 'mordred'}, {'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 1736, 'name': 'Ivan Kolodyazhny', 'email': 'e0ne@e0ne.info', 'username': 'e0ne'}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 4257, 'name': 'Zane Bitter', 'email': 'zbitter@redhat.com', 'username': 'zaneb'}, {'_account_id': 8556, 'name': 'Ghanshyam', 'display_name': 'Ghanshyam Mann', 'email': 'gmann@ghanshyammann.com', 'username': 'ghanshyam'}, {'_account_id': 10670, 'name': 'Michael McCune', 'email': 'elmiko@redhat.com', 'username': 'mimccune'}, {'_account_id': 11564, 'name': 'Chris Dent', 'email': 'cdent@anticdent.org', 'username': 'chdent'}, {'_account_id': 11628, 'name': 'Michael Johnson', 'email': 'johnsomor@gmail.com', 'username': 'johnsom'}, {'_account_id': 11655, 'name': 'Julia Kreger', 'email': 'juliaashleykreger@gmail.com', 'username': 'jkreger', 'status': 'On the moon! With a jetpack!'}, {'_account_id': 11904, 'name': 'Sean McGinnis', 'email': 'sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'username': 'SeanM'}, {'_account_id': 17068, 'name': 'Jean-Philippe Evrard', 'email': 'openstack@a.spamming.party', 'username': 'evrardjp'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-12-03 09:22:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-12-03 14:23:48.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-12-04 09:50:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-12-05 15:10:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

This is insufficiently clear about what kind of discovery it is doing and because this has been a source of much confusion throughout the years, I think we need to be very very clear.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-12-06 09:10:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-12-06 11:49:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2018-12-18 09:15:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'd like to see a thread on the ML to discuss this specific addition. I feel like we didn't get broad-enough input on this yet..."}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-12-18 23:45:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-12-21 06:44:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-12-21 06:52:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-12-21 07:18:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I'd like to see a thread on the ML to discuss this specific
 > addition. I feel like we didn't get broad-enough input on this
 > yet...

nice idea. Done - http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2018-December/001242.html"}, {'account_id': 10670, 'date': '2018-12-21 13:49:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

i think this reads well as a vision for version discover. i saw the email thread and just wanted to respond here with a link to the API SIG guidelines. there is some existing guidance[0] on how projects should implement version discovery from an api level. i don't think it's appropriate for the vision doc, but i wanted to make their existence more widely known.

[0] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-sig/guidelines/microversion_specification.html#version-discovery"}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-01-02 12:21:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote-1 Code-Review-1

(8 comments)

Lots of grammar suggestions within. That's the code-review -1.

The rollcall -1 is because of two things:

* I think we need much wider input on this before we take it too far
* because it is currently very vague about the mechanism of feature discovery. The version min/max version stuff already has a precedent, but discovering feature/version mappings is pretty unclear. It could be read here as "we should document feature/version mappings and users should be able to find that" or as "services need to provide an endpoint [with those mappings]". The email [1] says "Also, a user should be able to query detailed information about features and enhancement per version." but neither than thread nor this document really says what that means.

Overall I'm not convinced (at least as this is currently written) that version based feature discovery fits in with technical vision. It is am implementation detail that makes compatibility and interoperability work. The _vision_ is that we have high expectations that client code for one openstack cloud work with another openstack cloud with little to no modification. That's the critical piece.'}, {'account_id': 11628, 'date': '2019-01-02 19:38:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

It seems like we should have a documented "way" to do feature discovery before we add this to the vision statement.
Currently the documentation for API discoverability is: TODO
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-wg/guidelines/discoverability.html
It has been this way for years and there have been many discussions of different ways to do this, none of which have had any traction. This either means it's not important or we as a community need to have more discussions on the topic.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-01-02 20:03:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> It seems like we should have a documented "way" to do feature
 > discovery before we add this to the vision statement.
 > Currently the documentation for API discoverability is: TODO
 > https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-wg/guidelines/discoverability.html
 > It has been this way for years and there have been many discussions
 > of different ways to do this, none of which have had any traction.
 > This either means it's not important or we as a community need to
 > have more discussions on the topic.

The patch to resolve some of that todo is at https://review.openstack.org/#/c/459405/

As I said in my previous comment, I'm not sure the implementation matters for a _vision_ document. What matters is what we want to achieve (and why).

But either way, this still needs some work so we can find whatever the consensus is.'}, {'account_id': 10670, 'date': '2019-01-02 20:16:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> I'm not sure the implementation matters for a _vision_ document. What matters is what we want to achieve (and why).

++"}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-01-03 14:05:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Not sure yet, but this feels a little too low level of a detail for a vision doc.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-01-07 15:39:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Not sure yet, but this feels a little too low level of a detail for
 > a vision doc.

When I read all the comments here until now, it seems there is a consensus of being too detailed and not appropriate for a vision. I agree there.

Next to that, I think the current text is unclear about whether we are talking about exposing code version in a detailed manner for administrators with an API, or exposing feature sets based on said code versions for users.

As a deployer, I would totally love checking what the current (running code) version is for an endpoint. But that sounds more like a new implementation (and eventually a community goal for universal adoption) than a vision statement. But I may be out of my league there :p'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-01-17 12:29:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(8 comments)

> (8 comments)
 > 
 > Lots of grammar suggestions within. That's the code-review -1.
 > 
 > The rollcall -1 is because of two things:
 > 
 > * I think we need much wider input on this before we take it too
 > far
 > * because it is currently very vague about the mechanism of feature
 > discovery. The version min/max version stuff already has a
 > precedent, but discovering feature/version mappings is pretty
 > unclear. It could be read here as "we should document
 > feature/version mappings and users should be able to find that" or
 > as "services need to provide an endpoint [with those mappings]".
 > The email [1] says "Also, a user should be able to query detailed
 > information about features and enhancement per version." but
 > neither than thread nor this document really says what that means.
 > 
 > Overall I'm not convinced (at least as this is currently written)
 > that version based feature discovery fits in with technical vision.
 > It is am implementation detail that makes compatibility and
 > interoperability work. The _vision_ is that we have high
 > expectations that client code for one openstack cloud work with
 > another openstack cloud with little to no modification. That's the
 > critical piece.

Thanks for review Chris. main motive of adding feature discovery is to let user know the details about what is available with all different version of API provided by openstack services and they can know the cross service version compatibility. 

I know there is no clear mechanism/implementation of dynamic feature discovery in OpenStack so I am targetting this only for API version based feature discovery. 

I mean to add the endpoint in API to know the version based features details not just document. Having endpoint is best and easy way for user to query. I did not add that in this doc as that is more implementation details. But I can mention that if you think valuable.

This section is not only cover interoperability and compatibility but also I will say this makes "OpenStack services provide the enough information for their available API versions for better usage"

I will try to modify the details as per high level expectation as current one convey the implementation vision.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-01-17 12:31:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> i think this reads well as a vision for version discover. i saw the
 > email thread and just wanted to respond here with a link to the API
 > SIG guidelines. there is some existing guidance[0] on how projects
 > should implement version discovery from an api level. i don't think
 > it's appropriate for the vision doc, but i wanted to make their
 > existence more widely known.
 > 
 > [0] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-sig/guidelines/microversion_specification.html#version-discovery

Thanks, yeah that is the good doc for API microversion details doc which came from nova originally when we were implementing microverison during kilo. But not all projects are comfortable or going with microversion and there are other way also being adopted by many projects."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-01-17 12:35:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> > Not sure yet, but this feels a little too low level of a detail
 > for
 > > a vision doc.
 > 
 > When I read all the comments here until now, it seems there is a
 > consensus of being too detailed and not appropriate for a vision. I
 > agree there.
 > 
 > Next to that, I think the current text is unclear about whether we
 > are talking about exposing code version in a detailed manner for
 > administrators with an API, or exposing feature sets based on said
 > code versions for users.
 > 
 > As a deployer, I would totally love checking what the current
 > (running code) version is for an endpoint. But that sounds more
 > like a new implementation (and eventually a community goal for
 > universal adoption) than a vision statement. But I may be out of my
 > league there :p

My main motive here is to solve the problem of "OpenStack services provide too many API versions but openstack does not provide the way to user to know the changes/features per version etc".

This is very important from openstack user perspective when they try or continue using it. Many services are changing/increasing the API version too fast and having this kind of vision for those services is good to know.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-01-17 12:56:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-01-21 18:16:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Rollcall-Vote-1

(6 comments)

I'm worried that this is nice in theory, but I'm worried we're kind of looking at this in such a way that begins to multiply. I wonder if maybe the approach is maybe "what can I do" and a not "what might I be able to do" interface. I also have a practical operational security concern from revealing too much of how something is configured in the deployment in order to understand how or what options may be available.

I also wonder if we're thinking purely via API means, or is copious duplicated documentation sufficient?  Projects convey information in release notes, documentation, api-ref examples including API versions, and and component compatibility or requirements when crossing project boundaries.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-01-22 22:40:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

As written, this would be the longest section in the vision (with only the one about the Self-Service pillar even really coming close). That's a strong indication to me that we have *way* too much detail in here.

I'd be happy to see a paragraph tacked on the end of the Bidrectional Compatibility section that says something along the lines of:

"Changes to public APIs should be versioned and phased in, with a common mechanism to allow client introspection of the available versions."

That seems like about the right level of detail to me. I don't even think it's saying a different thing to the existing Bidirectional Compatibility section, just being slightly more prescriptive about how we intend to achieve it (which, to be clear, we have done elsewhere and would be a Good Thing IMHO).'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-01-23 05:11:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(3 comments)

> (6 comments)
 > 
 > I'm worried that this is nice in theory, but I'm worried we're kind
 > of looking at this in such a way that begins to multiply. I wonder
 > if maybe the approach is maybe "what can I do" and a not "what
 > might I be able to do" interface. I also have a practical
 > operational security concern from revealing too much of how
 > something is configured in the deployment in order to understand
 > how or what options may be available.
 > 
 > I also wonder if we're thinking purely via API means, or is copious
 > duplicated documentation sufficient?  Projects convey information
 > in release notes, documentation, api-ref examples including API
 > versions, and and component compatibility or requirements when
 > crossing project boundaries.

I agree that all that information can be found in reno, api-ref or doc but that is too difficult for users to know from. If APIs can provide a way for user to query about details of API version then, it is the easiest thing for user. 

As user/application, I do not want to search the reno or ton of documentation or code to know the details of API version. 

For security point, I think those can be handled with appropriate permissions on such info via RBAC etc.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-01-23 05:19:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> As written, this would be the longest section in the vision (with
 > only the one about the Self-Service pillar even really coming
 > close). That's a strong indication to me that we have *way* too
 > much detail in here.
 > 
 > I'd be happy to see a paragraph tacked on the end of the
 > Bidrectional Compatibility section that says something along the
 > lines of:
 > 
 > "Changes to public APIs should be versioned and phased in, with a
 > common mechanism to allow client introspection of the available
 > versions."
 > 
 > That seems like about the right level of detail to me. I don't even
 > think it's saying a different thing to the existing Bidirectional
 > Compatibility section, just being slightly more prescriptive about
 > how we intend to achieve it (which, to be clear, we have done
 > elsewhere and would be a Good Thing IMHO).

IMO, having a detailed separate section about providing the way to a user about the discovery of API version based features convey the technical vision more precisely.  It is the easy and very consistent way if as user/app I can query API and get to know all details of each API version. Otherwise I end up searching doc, reno, code to know that. 

I agree on the point(from almost all of you) that it is too detailed for vision doc but conveying it in more detail way is better I feel. 

If the project (existing/new) understand it clearly even (it states little low level details) and implement, IMO that is good consistent mechanism that openstack projects can provide to users.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-01-23 20:54:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

The detail is a useful thing to have, but it can live somewhere like the API WG docs. We don't want the TC mandating technical solutions, and we don't need the vision to go down the rabbithole on this one topic when it manages to cover vastly more complex topics (multitenancy: good) in much less space."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-01-24 10:51:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

> The detail is a useful thing to have, but it can live somewhere
 > like the API WG docs. We don't want the TC mandating technical
 > solutions, and we don't need the vision to go down the rabbithole
 > on this one topic when it manages to cover vastly more complex
 > topics (multitenancy: good) in much less space.

Agree with all this. As an api-sig alum, I can assure that this level of detail is exactly what the API guidelines want and need, and in fact there is quite a bit of that information in there already, and some stuff pending: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/459405/

_This_ document is very much not the place for details. It's about providing vision/goals which can be used to inform details. As such "Features should be discoverable" is almost enough.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-01-24 14:14:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Rollcall-Vote-1

I agree with others here and still believe the vision document is not the right place for this.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-01-28 08:00:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow-1

Thanks everyone for your input. I will avoid the details here and will add some high level expectation from vision point of view.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-01-28 08:28:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-01-28 14:03:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

Thanks for trimming this way back, I think this is much better for the vision doc. Slight suggestion within.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-01-29 08:29:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-01-29 08:30:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Published edit on patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-01-29 09:08:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Rollcall-Vote+1

Can't argue with this :)"}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-01-29 09:08:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Rollcall-Vote+1

The current wording is acceptable to me, as it represents what we want to achieve for our users. It doesn't entail deep practical details, and trust the projects to achieve that goal."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-01-29 09:16:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-01-29 14:47:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-01-30 08:19:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-01-30 14:55:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Rollcall-Vote+1

yes let's do that"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-02-04 17:06:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Add Version Based Feature Discovery in Technical Vision

As discussed in original proposal of OpenStack Technical
Vision patch[1] and in summit also[2], this commit adds
the "Version Based Feature Discovery" information under
Bidrectional Compatibility section.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/592205/5/reference/technical-vision.rst@132
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2018-December/000431.html

Change-Id: I4a3bb3a2df80ad65df47e937b506f7ac2500a158

Add amphora statistics to the admin API

This patch adds an admin API for getting per-amphora statistics.

commit_message:
Ignore MoxStubout deprecation warnings

Mox usage in glance isn't going anywhere anytime
soon, so let's ignore these warnings so they don't
choke the console logs on test runs.

The actual invocation of the WarningsFixture needed
to be moved to *before* using the MoxStubout fixture
otherwise it has no use.

Change-Id: Ife243f5382f085b09e26b53f8f5518bc35cc8a43
Closes-Bug: #1778784

commit_message:
Mariadb: Use correct credentials for exporter in secret

This updates the mariadb chart to use the correct auth values for
the mariadb prometheus exporter. The correct credentials to use
are the credentials in the oslo_db endpoint

Change-Id: I2d325167d7ffdf911a56fe97b879cb13b0d4c195

commit_message:
FWaaS v1->v2 DB migration

FWaaS V1 is expected to be deleted on the Stein cycle.
This patch introduces a new tool the DB migration from FWaaS v1 to FWaaS V2.

Run this tool using: neutron-fwaas-migrate-v1-to-v2 --neutron-db-connection=<neutron database connection string>

Change-Id: I663c173a594137056c96ad4c4b60e810059fb6fa

[{'account_id': 29811, 'date': '2019-01-17 07:55:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-01-17 07:55:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-01-17 09:54:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Hello WEN-SHENG LI,

I noticed you had submitted your first patch to OpenStack! Congratulations! I just wanted to reach out and follow up with you on the comments on your patch to see if you need any help. We want to help you get your patch merged and help you be successful in our community! 

Please let us know if you have any questions about your patch, the review process, or the community itself. 

I have added a Nova dev, Ghanshyam Mann, to your patch who can help you along your OpenStack journey!

Hope to hear from you soon, 

Matthew Oliver (mattoliverau) and the rest of the First Contact SIG'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-01-30 06:58:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Delete floating IPs on network turned internal

The neutron-lib part of this change: https://review.openstack.org/624751

This change introduces a new shim extension
(floatingip-autodelete-internal) to signal a change in API behavior
introduced by the fix of a bug referred below. That is now we autodelete
unused floating IPs when changing a network to router:external=False.

It also documents the API change.

Change-Id: I247106e95abb5d6822aa35ae793531a1d79edbd4
Needed-By: https://review.openstack.org/624751
Partial-Bug: #1806032

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-04-18 14:46:31.000000000', 'message': 'Add project info to server list from all projects

When listing servers from all projects, the project, where each server
belongs to, is not shown. A cloud admin may list thousands of servers
and it would be really helpful to have this information available.

This commit, adds the project info for each listed server when using
the all-projects param.

The project info follows the example of flavor and image information:

When using just the --all param, the project name is shown for each
listed server.
When the --all and --no-name-lookup params, the project id is shown
instead.
When using the --all and --long params, both the project name and id
are listed.

Instead of hardcoding both the column headers and the server fields
before forming the table, a new mechanism for mapping column headers
to server fields is introduced.

Change-Id: I14d6711e538e217e965c6aae3338e7687c40dcfc
Closes-Bug: #1732216

commit_message:
Add project info to server list from all projects

When listing servers from all projects, the project, where each server
belongs to, is not shown. A cloud admin may list thousands of servers
and it would be really helpful to have this information available.

This commit, adds the project info for each listed server when using
the all-projects param.

The project info follows the example of flavor and image information:

When using just the --all param, the project name is shown for each
listed server.
When the --all and --no-name-lookup params, the project id is shown
instead.
When using the --all and --long params, both the project name and id
are listed.

Instead of hardcoding both the column headers and the server fields
before forming the table, a new mechanism for mapping column headers
to server fields is introduced.

Change-Id: I14d6711e538e217e965c6aae3338e7687c40dcfc
Story: #2001867
Task: #14321

commit_message:
Add mock as a requirement for python-vmware-nsx

The module mock is listed in vmware-nsx's requirements.txt
file. But the spec file template is missing the python-mock
package.

Change-Id: I117f50d8e62560730bb8bde37056f09ab4e60de2

commit_message:
Rely on osa defaults for enabled services

Tripleo should rely on openshift-ansible defaults as much as possible,
especially concerning the services which are enabled.

This removes the setting that explicitly disabled the service catalog
and template service broker, and wire in the ansible-service-broker
from heat parameters. The service-catalog and template-service-broker
images do not need to be specified since they're derived from the
oreg_url in openshift-ansible.

commit_message:
Loop over *all* containers in order to get the container STDOUT

This is mandatory if we want to be able to know the reasons a
container is in "Exited (non-Zero)" state. Until now, we got
only the currently running containers stdout, and this has, in
fact, only little interest.

Change-Id: I94917543a9d058c911d04e083d7e9cd32335eb44

messages:
[{'account_id': 2394, 'date': '2019-01-23 23:08:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-01-24 10:45:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)

This is a really good point. We emphasise sentence case over capital case in the documentation, but we've never really discussed it from a UI perspective. I wonder if Jimmy has any thoughts on this one too (sorry Jimmy).
Personally, I quite like the capital case in the actual UI as long as the documentation titles continue in sentence case."}, {'account_id': 20156, 'date': '2019-01-29 15:39:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-23 23:08:38.000000000', 'message': 'Fix over-capitalization of <h3> headings

It is generally considered good style not to necessarily capitalize
every single word in titles, e.g.

  https://grammar.yourdictionary.com/capitalization/rules-for-capitalization-in-titles.html

Presumably this is intended to include sub-headings too.

In fact, the OpenStack Documentation Contributor Guide goes even
further away from all capitals:

    Use the following guidelines for all types of headings:

      * Use sentence-style capitalization.
      * ...

    -- https://docs.openstack.org/doc-contrib-guide/writing-style/headings.html

And looking at files such as www/stein/user/index.html, we find headings
such as:

    User Guides for OpenStack Services

and

    User Guides for OpenStack Deployment Tools

where the intention for a lowercase "for" is clear.

So remove the CSS which automatically capitalizes every single word in
headings, and lowercase any remaining articles, prepositions, or
coordinating conjunctions.

Change-Id: I7cc35a1528c0e15c4e1d1fc47d27c2d4ab49e497
'}]
commit_message:
Fix over-capitalization of <h3> headings

It is generally considered good style not to necessarily capitalize
every single word in titles, e.g.

  https://grammar.yourdictionary.com/capitalization/rules-for-capitalization-in-titles.html

Presumably this is intended to include sub-headings too.

In fact, the OpenStack Documentation Contributor Guide goes even
further away from all capitals:

    Use the following guidelines for all types of headings:

      * Use sentence-style capitalization.
      * ...

    -- https://docs.openstack.org/doc-contrib-guide/writing-style/headings.html

And looking at files such as www/stein/user/index.html, we find headings
such as:

    User Guides for OpenStack Services

and

    User Guides for OpenStack Deployment Tools

where the intention for a lowercase "for" is clear.

So remove the CSS which automatically capitalizes every single word in
headings, and lowercase any remaining articles, prepositions, or
coordinating conjunctions.

Change-Id: I7cc35a1528c0e15c4e1d1fc47d27c2d4ab49e497

commit_message:
Fixed UnicodeEncodeError for Python2 unicode objects

On python2 in case of unicode objects, str() was causing UnicodeEncodeError.
Also utf8 encoding as a default (mostly for Python2)

Change-Id: I64373133f65c5b11daa3462b7c21a55d06738c09

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: Iffa4a6293d16b6635af9a2da11a99b02f0d85a96
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

See
http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/sahara-tests/tree/.zuul.yaml#n87

http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/python-saharaclient/tree/.zuul.yaml

 > be

fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: Id70d6e6af5bb731253c331bafde27b4970f3fe6f
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

In general I'd love if we can get memcached in keystone integrated by default (if it indeed proves that performance is improved). The failover story is a different one and I think we need to write up a bit the semantics of what happens when the configured memcache server (or servers) are not available.

Do we really want this since we are switching to os_tempest? If so, at least add a todo to remove it in the near future.'}, {'account_id': 12393, 'date': '2019-02-04 10:53:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

We need to enable telemetry tests from skip list so weneed it, once we move to os_tempest role we can remove it'}, {'account_id': 12393, 'date': '2019-02-04 10:57:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> > Do we really want this since we are switching to os_tempest? If
 > so,
 > > at least add a todo to remove it in the near future.
 > 
 > We need to enable telemetry tests from skip list so weneed it, once
 > we move to os_tempest role we can remove it

Currently on validate-tempest role changes (where skip list is present, can be reused with os_tempest while moving). Different standalone scenario jobs runs different tests, since people will add the tests to the skip list but in order to make sure it works, we need to need to make sure the tests gating added to the skip list passes the gates. Without standalone scenario full job, we cannot confirm.
For example: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/604311/ -> removes telemetry tests which runs in scenario01, if we add this job, then we can know it is working fine against TQE.'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2019-02-04 12:14:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Enable standalone-full on validate-tempest role

Tempest is the integral piece of testing TripleO. Validate-temepst
role contains the skip list so it is necessary to run full standalone
jobs so that any changes in skip list working or not.

Change-Id: Iebfa7bb5ddeb823bacc51ba618e0028af7db627d

[{'created': '2019-02-04 14:13:43.000000000', 'message': 'Fix Queens+ S3 auth

Commit e92e8a7 changed the order of auth middleware in the proxy
pipeline which causes S3 api requests to get a 403 error. This
fixes it.

Change-Id: I7d932e9cc843088e9c9420c9d35455d09aec6993
'}]
commit_message:
Fix Queens+ S3 auth

Commit e92e8a7 changed the order of auth middleware in the proxy
pipeline which causes S3 api requests to get a 403 error. This
fixes it.

Change-Id: I7d932e9cc843088e9c9420c9d35455d09aec6993

commit_message:
use include_tasks and import_playbook instead of include

include is marked as deprecated since ansible 2.4[0]

Switch to include_tasks or import_playbook as necessary

commit_message:
Disable nonfunctional experimental check jobs

This disables the centos and fedora experimental checks, as they
need work to resolve issues before they can begin to add value

[{'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2019-01-31 22:24:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2019-02-01 08:03:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

tripleo-ci-centos-7-containerized-under-cloud-upgrades seems to fail for an unrelated reason (some docker containers can't be stopped and replaced by podman containers).

from the logs I can see that docker container for mysql got stopped as expected [1]:
8ad795cb6787        docker.io/tripleorocky/centos-binary-mariadb:527553752a2a927ea0f505bd7f977e33fa7b6790_2609fa81                      "dumb-init --singl..."   57 minutes ago      Exited (137) 22 minutes ago                        mysql                                         1.68 kB (virtual 957 MB)
 
and a podman container got recreated [2]:
5fd7e8724ae1  docker.io/tripleomaster/centos-binary-mariadb:e4a542b9a3ea6f459605ffbaa3c8af97eb81921f_a9a57ed8                     dumb-init --singl...  9 minutes ago   Up 9 minutes ago                   mysql                                        1.68kB (virtual 788MB)


[1] http://logs.openstack.org/30/634330/1/check/tripleo-ci-centos-7-containerized-undercloud-upgrades/94198d2/logs/undercloud/var/log/extra/docker/docker_allinfo.log.txt.gz
[2] http://logs.openstack.org/30/634330/1/check/tripleo-ci-centos-7-containerized-undercloud-upgrades/94198d2/logs/undercloud/var/log/extra/podman/podman_allinfo.log.txt.gz'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2019-02-03 20:02:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2019-02-03 21:28:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2019-02-04 08:01:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-31 22:24:02.000000000', 'message': 'mysql: do not stop container when upgrade doesn't update mysql image

In 0015cc74416445c3cf4e18e566a954f609f7cf0f we added the ability
to stop gracefully the mysql container during a major upgrade, to
allow upgrade to versions of mysql with different redo log format [1].

Stopping mysql is OK as long as paunch restarts it during the deploy
tasks. However, paunch only (re)start mysql if the mysql config hash
changes, it doesn't check whether mysql is stopped or not. So running
"undercloud upgrade" with identical mysql container image now fails.

Fix the upgrade strategy by stopping mysql only when needed, that is
when mysql container image is to be updated.

[1] https://jira.mariadb.org/browse/MDEV-14848

Change-Id: I88f1913581e6c9e279bcaf99ad4260dd940636c3
'}]
commit_message:
mysql: do not stop container when upgrade doesn't update mysql image

In 0015cc74416445c3cf4e18e566a954f609f7cf0f we added the ability
to stop gracefully the mysql container during a major upgrade, to
allow upgrade to versions of mysql with different redo log format [1].

Stopping mysql is OK as long as paunch restarts it during the deploy
tasks. However, paunch only (re)start mysql if the mysql config hash
changes, it doesn't check whether mysql is stopped or not. So running
"undercloud upgrade" with identical mysql container image now fails.

Fix the upgrade strategy by stopping mysql only when needed, that is
when mysql container image is to be updated.

[1] https://jira.mariadb.org/browse/MDEV-14848

Change-Id: I88f1913581e6c9e279bcaf99ad4260dd940636c3

Currently Octavia sends out the updated difference to provider

Change-Id: Ie946fa3559bafb95fd75d09f705ab2811bb9584b

commit_message:
TrivialFix : Verify Listener Protocol

Currently Octavia sends out the updated difference to provider
driver when LoadBalancer API is called. This means that if the
Listener Protocol is not changed during Listener Update, then
Octavia will pass Unset as Listener Protocol. This patch verifies
if the protocol is actually updated when listener update request
is received by OVN.

Change-Id: Ie946fa3559bafb95fd75d09f705ab2811bb9584b

commit_message:
Retrieve network_data only when it is available otherwise skip it

Currently while processing template network_data is collected from
template sometime templates does not have data and on that data we
are running a for loop which will break the deployment it is good
we can skip the step.

Change-Id: I282dfc92fc67864901b82d4eaecf013c1bd7cab8
Closes-Bug: #1814516

commit_message:
service: updates nova-api-os-compute service to use apache wsgi

Due to an issue in python3 oslo_cache+eventlet when using
memcached. As workaroud for Rocky it has been decided to run service
nova-api-os-compute from systemd to apache2.

Closes-Bug: #1812672
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/633218
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/633482
Change-Id: I3bf279638c5decf1020345f3d2e876e379144997
Signed-off-by: Sahid Orentino Ferdjaoui <sahid.ferdjaoui@canonical.com>

context: extend HAProxyContext for placement API

commit_message:
Drop config option 'logs' and 'logs-search' from [service_available]

Both options are never used and there is already
[service_available]monasca which will be used (see [1]) to detect if
Monasca tempest tests should be executed.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/634386/

Change-Id: I067af2952ba811fffb38faf5af2bc54c988e5ad0
Story: 2004917
Task: 29278

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-12-13 14:09:04.000000000', 'message': 'Set [pxe] tftp_server in ironic.conf

The ironic TFTP server should be accessed via the internal API network.
For ironic inspector, dnsmasq.conf advertises this correctly:

dhcp-option=option:tftp-server,{{ api_interface_address }}
dhcp-option=option:server-ip-address,{{ api_interface_address }}

However, ironic conductor does not set the [pxe] tftp_server variable.
This means the TFTP server advertised gets the default value of $my_ip,
which is set by
https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.utils/latest/reference/netutils.html#oslo_utils.netutils.get_my_ipv4,
typically the source IP for the default route.

This change sets [pxe] tftp_server to {{ api_interface_address }}.

Change-Id: Ic3e688b3f2b92ad9515322f49cd5f4f29d763e49
Closes-Bug: #1808347
'}, {'created': '2019-02-04 09:48:56.000000000', 'message': "Set [pxe] tftp_server in ironic.conf

The ironic TFTP server should be accessed via the internal API network.
For ironic inspector, dnsmasq.conf advertises this correctly:

dhcp-option=option:tftp-server,'api_interface_address'
dhcp-option=option:server-ip-address,'api_interface_address'

However, ironic conductor does not set the [pxe] tftp_server variable.
This means the TFTP server advertised gets the default value of $my_ip,
which is set by
https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.utils/latest/reference/netutils.html#oslo_utils.netutils.get_my_ipv4,
typically the source IP for the default route.

This change sets [pxe] tftp_server to 'api_interface_address'.

Change-Id: Ic3e688b3f2b92ad9515322f49cd5f4f29d763e49
Closes-Bug: #1808347
"}]
commit_message:
Set [pxe] tftp_server in ironic.conf

The ironic TFTP server should be accessed via the internal API network.
For ironic inspector, dnsmasq.conf advertises this correctly:

dhcp-option=option:tftp-server,'api_interface_address'
dhcp-option=option:server-ip-address,'api_interface_address'

However, ironic conductor does not set the [pxe] tftp_server variable.
This means the TFTP server advertised gets the default value of $my_ip,
which is set by
https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.utils/latest/reference/netutils.html#oslo_utils.netutils.get_my_ipv4,
typically the source IP for the default route.

This change sets [pxe] tftp_server to 'api_interface_address'.

Change-Id: Ic3e688b3f2b92ad9515322f49cd5f4f29d763e49
Closes-Bug: #1808347

commit_message:
template: update conf template for placement-api

Currently we directly use the one provided by charmhelper which does
not allow to reuse it for an other service. In this commit we symlink
a new template called wsgi-placement-api.conf to
charmhelper/../wsgi-openstack-api.conf.

The disable_package_apache2_site() call has been added in
do_openstack_upgrade() since previously it was not necessary to have
it during this step.

The disable_package_apache2_site() call has been added in
upgrade-charm to ensure that we remove old wsgi config for users which
are already using bionic-rocky and are upgrading their charm.

Partial-Bug: #1812672
Change-Id: Idc3cad9304eaf9b610db20650c32cd754f016358
Signed-off-by: Sahid Orentino Ferdjaoui <sahid.ferdjaoui@canonical.com>

commit_message:
use payloads for PORT BEFORE_DELETE callbacks

This patch switches BEFORE_DELETE callback events for PORT resources
over to the payload style args use a DBEventPayload object in prep for
the depends on patch.

Change-Id: I8b4b0387f6934c3f1001d3aada5c47a784d3706a

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-21 16:26:42.000000000', 'message': 'clustering: guard on hostname presentation

Deployment environments may have random features with regards to
forward/reverse hostname lookups; the charm does endeavour to
write reliable hostname/ip maps into /etc/hosts however not all
functions that assess the ready-ness of the cluster to form
look at whether this has been presented.

Update the is_sufficient_peers check to validate with this key
and use during changes on the cluster relation to avoid cluster
host discovery for unresolvable hostnames as a side effect of
peers within the cluster discovering each other outside of the
charm code.

Change-Id: I27d6356dba4340388211c6dfed383417c35542e0
Closes-Bug: 1812672
'}, {'created': '2019-01-21 16:29:59.000000000', 'message': 'clustering: guard on hostname presentation

Update the is_sufficient_peers check to validate with this key
and use during changes on the cluster relation to avoid cluster

peers within the cluster discovering each other outside of the
charm code.

Change-Id: I27d6356dba4340388211c6dfed383417c35542e0
Closes-Bug: 1812568
'}]
commit_message:
clustering: guard on hostname presentation

Deployment environments may have random features with regards to
forward/reverse hostname lookups; the charm does endeavour to
write reliable hostname/ip maps into /etc/hosts however not all
functions that assess the ready-ness of the cluster to form
look at whether this has been presented.

Update the is_sufficient_peers check to validate with this key
and use during changes on the cluster relation to avoid cluster
host discovery for unresolvable hostnames as a side effect of
peers within the cluster discovering each other outside of the
charm code.

Change-Id: I27d6356dba4340388211c6dfed383417c35542e0
Closes-Bug: 1812568

commit_message:
Set project_id when creating SG rule

Due to the neutron patch [1] recently merged, kuryr is breaking
on SG rule creation. This commit partially fixes the issue
by specifying the project_id on SG rule creation.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/628691

Change-Id: Id9ad11002f7939e1a74b6ad59f6d8c947fe9faec
Partial-Bug: 1813756

'}, {'created': '2019-02-04 07:35:51.000000000', 'message': 'Add tox minversion in tox.ini

It is always safe to define the minimal tox version required to run,
if the host tox is less than this the tool with exit with an error
message indicating the user needs to upgrade tox.

For ref: https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#tox-global-settings

Change-Id: I803958fc7d7c9a8c99609f190415e764587eb705
'}]
commit_message:
Add tox minversion in tox.ini

It is always safe to define the minimal tox version required to run,
if the host tox is less than this the tool with exit with an error
message indicating the user needs to upgrade tox.

For ref: https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/config.html#tox-global-settings

Change-Id: I803958fc7d7c9a8c99609f190415e764587eb705

commit_message:
Remove unreachable code

Infra driver create method will either raise Exception or it will
return valid instance Id.
The exception is well handled in the code so removed the unreachable
code.

Change-Id: Ie498ca80e704d06fab0a2cbac3f417acadcaf747

commit_message:
Add volume-group table actions for admin panel

This commit allows admin to perform the following
table action :
1. manage volumes (Add/remove volumes from group),
2. remove all volumes from group
3. delete group

Partially-Implements blueprint cinder-generic-volume-groups

Change-Id: I7fcc0dfa8195ecb7914a883fec85c573caa4ae86

commit_message:
Omit dahsboard on elk setup by default

With the introduction of the "infrustructure" panel and "canvas" becoming
stable, there's not a lot of reason to import the  general beat dashboards.
The default dashboard are almost always in a state of disrepare and take a
long time to import on high traffic clusters.

This channge removes the default dashboard from the beat setup role by
default. If a deployer wishes to renable the default dashboards, or add any
other beat flags, the variable `elastic_setup_flags` can be used to extend
the setup.

Change-Id: If44845f53e4d0cb1e91ec804060316fb852b4bfa
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin@cloudnull.com>

[{'created': '2019-01-23 00:31:35.000000000', 'message': "Fix untrusted dashboard host

The `openstack_auth login` view uses `request.build_absolute_uri` function
to build an origin url when websso is enabled and
the WEBSSO_DEFAULT_REDIRECT_PROTOCOL is set.
This funchion doesn't insert the `WEBROOT` variable into uri what causes an

Using the `build_absolute_uri` from `utils` module fixes this problem. It

commit_message:
Fix untrusted dashboard host

The `openstack_auth login` view uses `request.build_absolute_uri` function
to build an origin uri when websso is enabled and
the WEBSSO_DEFAULT_REDIRECT_PROTOCOL is set.
This function doesn't insert the `WEBROOT` variable into uri what causes an
error:
    http://domain.name/auth/websso/ is not a trusted dashboard host
Using the `build_absolute_uri` from `utils` module fixes this problem. It
generates the right uri:
    http://domain.name/dashboard/auth/websso/

Change-Id: I94100f66a9f07eb8da75d344cbd120838fe25d1e
